thread.title_full: Rupee Poll: Rupee to weaken but may not breach 66/$ | Business Standard News

author: Neelasri Barman & Abhijit Lele
title: Rupee Poll: Rupee to weaken but may not breach 66/$ News
text:
In the absence of major intervention by the central bank the rupee could further weaken to the dollar but unlike to cross 66 per dollar mark, according to a poll conducted by Business Standard.

The median forecast of the 10 experts showed rupee at 65.40/4 a month down the line. Only two respondents said rupee will above 66/4 dollar.

The rupee came under pressure amid volatile global markets with investors moved away from riskier assets after China started devaluing its currency for two successive days. The rupee fell about 1.9% in the last three trading sessions, which closed at 65.11/$ today.

"The overall currency devaluation is being trigger by the Chinese yuan. That will continue to keep the rupee weaker. To be competitive, RBI will not be too uncomfortable with the rupee at around 65-65.50 per dollar," Anindya Banerjee, currency analyst, Kotak Securities.

Today China devalued its currency by another 1.1% to the dollar, bringing the total devaluation by 4.4% in three days, the biggest drop in decades. The move was triggered after weak July export data. There is a speculation that Beijing's action will trigger a currency war among nations.
"I don't know where the rupee is headed. But what China is doing is very dangerous and unpredictable. They have devalued the Yuan twice in two days. Unless something is done, it will lead to competitive devaluation. I think either competitive devaluation or duty on China globally is a distinct possibility," said Aditya Puri, managing director, HDFC Bank.

RBI was not seen aggressive is defending the rupee though it is in an better position as compared to the currency crisis that the country faced two years back. The country's foreign exchange reserves swelled from $ 274 billion from September 2013 to over $ 350 billion now which resulted in impot cover moving up to 9 months from 7 months.

INR is now amongst the best performing currencies since May 2013, the time of the taper tantrum. While easing energy prices, robust FDI and a longer period of easy global monetary policy are welcome news for India, INR does need to weaken, to stave off the prospects of further cheap imports from China and elsewhere.

"A gentle depreciation in the rupee would be welcome news for India. Given global FX moves, this will help bring the REER to more reasonable levels, from the 11% overvaluation today. We still have large levels of unhedged foreign currency exposures. Hopefully, further monetary policy easing in India will help address this as well," said Ananth Narayan, Regional Head- Financial markets, South Asia, Standard Chartered.

A section of market participants the Indian currency to strengthen once the present volatility taper off.

"Rupee will move up to 64.5 per dollar in fortnight to one month time frame. In September and beyond, the price trends for rupee would be influenced by US Federal Reserve action. If it decides to keep policy rates unchanged, Rupee will only appreciate further," said N S Venkatesh, Executive director and head of treasury, IDBI Bank.
